messageBody:
Interesting. It's too bad that some of the reforms you mentioned
didn't catch on. It's also *really* too bad that diacritics were not
considered essential by those who developed ASCII--it would certainly
make it easier to come up with a good mapping for QS if they had been.

Ted

On Jan 11, 2008 6:02 AM, Benct Philip Jonsson <bpj@...> wrote:
>
>
>
>
>
>
> On 10.1.2008 Ted Larson Freeman wrote:
> > Well, if there were enough vowels in the Roman alphabet
> > for the English language, we wouldn't be working on an
> > alphabetic reform project, would we?
> >
>
> Those two things are not necessarily connected. If the roman
> alphabet had twenty vowel signs, but these were mapped to
> the twelve monophthongs and seven diphthongs of Middle
> English the need for reform could still be strongly felt.
> Even more so if Middle English had had fourteen vowel signs
> and ignored length, in which case the Great Vowel shift
> would have made as big a mess anyway! (see
> <http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Great_vowel_shift>, especially
> the very informative graphic. This is not to say that a
> satisfactory orthography based on the Roman alphabet could
> have been created in the 16th and 17th centuries in England
> as it was in the rest of Northern Europe. Nowhere was there
> a complete break with Medieval tradition, nor was there
> anywhere -- even in England -- a total lack of reform.
>
> Several reforms in vowel spelling were attempted in 16th
> century England:
>
> * To abolish the use use of silent e in favor of digraphs
> (aa staat, ee compleet, ij polijt).
> * To introduce new digraphs, diacritics and even new letters
> (from the Greek alphabet).
> * To differentiate j from i and v from u.
> * To differentiate ea from ee and oa/o-e from oo.
>
> As we know only the last two had any success, and the effect
> of the last was partly undone by the meet-meat merger in the
> 17th century.
>
> It is notable that a digraph like ou was multivalued already
> in Middle English, and apparently nobody was able to come up
> with any real good idea for how to solve that.
>
> Much ink has been spilled on why the English proved more
> conservative, and why the English-speaking nations continue
> to be afraid of diacritics.
>
> See:
> <http://www.chass.utoronto.ca/~cpercy/courses/6362Olague1.htm>
>
